title: John Prentice (footballer, born 1926)
text:
John Prentice (2 August 1926 – 10 February 2006) was a Scottish <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and manager. He played for <a href="Heart%20of%20Midlothian%20F.C.">Heart of Midlothian</a>, <a href="Rangers%20F.C.">Rangers</a>, <a href="Falkirk%20F.C.">Falkirk</a> and <a href="Dumbarton%20F.C.">Dumbarton</a>, and managed <a href="Arbroath%20F.C.">Arbroath</a>, Falkirk, <a href="Dundee%20F.C.">Dundee</a>, <a href="Clyde%20F.C.">Clyde</a> and <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a>.
Club career.
Prentice was born in <a href="Shotts">Shotts</a>, <a href="Lanarkshire">Lanarkshire</a>. After playing for the non-league club Carluke Rovers, Prentice signed for Hearts in 1944. A defender, he played for the <a href="Edinburgh">Edinburgh</a> side for seven years, before signing for Rangers in 1951 for £7000. He joined Falkirk in 1956 and the high point of his playing career was captaining Falkirk to their <a href="Scottish%20Cup">Scottish Cup</a> triumph over <a href="Kilmarnock%20F.C.">Kilmarnock</a> in the <a href="1957%20Scottish%20Cup%20Final">1957 Scottish Cup Final</a>. He left Falkirk in 1959 and signed for Dumbarton, where he finished his playing career. He also played for the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League%20XI">Scottish League representative team</a>.
Managerial career.
Arbroath.
Prentice began his managerial career at the age of 33 in April 1960, when he was appointed as manager of relegated First Division side <a href="Arbroath%20F.C.">Arbroath</a> and took up his post for the final two games of the <a href="1959%E2%80%9360%20in%20Scottish%20football">1959–60</a> season. In his first full season (<a href="1960%E2%80%9361%20in%20Scottish%20football">1960–61</a>), Arbroath finished in 12th place in the 19 team Second Division after he had controversially sold top striker Dave Easson to <a href="Raith%20Rovers%20F.C.">Raith Rovers</a>. In his second season, after a good start to the season, they finished in 6th place. Prentice suddenly resigned as manager in September 1962. No official reason was given for his exit, but a few weeks before his departure, Arbroath Town Council had refused to allocate him a house on the grounds that his job was not considered to be that of a '<a href="key%20worker">key worker</a>'.
Clyde.
In November 1962, he was appointed as manager of <a href="Clyde%20F.C.">Clyde</a>. In his first half-season he was unable to stop Clyde being relegated, but in 1964 he guided them to promotion as Second Division runners-up. In the <a href="1964%E2%80%9365%20in%20Scottish%20football">1964–65</a> season Clyde finished seventh in the eighteen team First Division and also played well in the following season.
Scotland National Team.
The quality of his team's performances and his management talents were recognized when, in March 1966, he was appointed as full-time manager of the <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland national football team</a>. He succeeded <a href="Jock%20Stein">Jock Stein</a>, who had managed the side on a part-time basis in addition to his post at <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a>. Prentice took charge of four games between April and June in 1966, all played at <a href="Hampden%20Park">Hampden Park</a>. Scotland suffered defeats by <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a>, the <a href="Netherlands%20national%20football%20team">Netherlands</a> and <a href="Portugal%20national%20football%20team">Portugal</a>, but recorded a 1–1 draw with reigning world champions <a href="Brazil%20national%20football%20team">Brazil</a> in his last game. This meant that Prentice statistically held the worst record of any Scotland manager in his first four matches in charge, until <a href="Berti%20Vogts">Berti Vogts</a> lost his first five matches in charge.
Later Club career.
Prentice returned to club management with his old club Falkirk in October 1966. He later managed Dundee, his only experience of managing in European competition but left in 1972 to return to Falkirk where he remained until 1975.
Retirement.
Prentice emigrated to Australia in the 1970s. He died in February 2006 of a <a href="brain%20tumour">brain tumour</a>, aged 79.
